meanings.def: difficult to do, understand or answer
examples: a hard choice/decision/question
hard to do something It is hard to believe that she's only nine.
It's hard to see how they can lose.
It's hard to imagine a more cynical political strategy.
‘When will the job be finished?’ ‘It's hard to say (= it is difficult to be certain)’ .
It's getting harder and harder to earn enough to pay the rent.
I find his attitude very hard to take (= difficult to accept).
We're finding reliable staff hard to come by (= difficult to get).
Houses like this are extremely hard to find.
You are hard to please, aren’t you?
I found it hard to believe what they told me.
hard for somebody It must be hard for her, bringing up four children on her own.
hard for somebody to do something It's hard for old people to change their ways.
I found the exam quite hard.
I always found languages quite hard at school.
Some viruses can be harder to identify.
The reason for their absence wasn't hard to find.
They were given a list of hard spellings to learn.
If you tell the children the answers, it only makes it harder for them to do the work on their own.
It can be very hard for people to accept change.

meanings.def: full of difficulty and problems, especially because of a lack of money
examples: Times were hard at the end of the war.
She's had a hard life.
Life got very hard.
Conditions were extremely hard in the camps.

meanings.def: needing or using a lot of physical strength or mental effort
examples: It's hard work shovelling snow.
This is the hardest part of my job.
It was one of the hardest things I ever did.
I've had a long hard day.
This season has been a hard slog.
They had put in hours of hard graft.
The exam questions were quite difficult.
It is difficult for young people to find jobs around here.
I always found languages quite hard at school.
It was one of the hardest things I ever did.
It is a technically demanding piece of music to play.
This shouldn’t be too taxing for you.

meanings.def: putting a lot of effort or energy into an activity
examples: She's a very hard worker.
He's hard at work on a new novel.
When I left they were all still hard at it (= working hard).

meanings.def: done with a lot of strength or force
examples: He gave the door a good hard kick.
a hard punch

meanings.def: solid or stiff and difficult to bend or break
examples: Wait for the concrete to go hard.
a hard mattress
Diamonds are the hardest known mineral.
The chairs felt hard and uncomfortable.
The ground is still rock-hard.

meanings.def: showing no kind feelings or sympathy
examples: My father was a hard man.
She gave me a hard stare.
His voice was hard.
He said some very hard things to me.

meanings.def: showing no signs of fear or weakness; ready to fight or compete
examples: Come and get me if you think you're hard enough.
You think you're really hard, don't you?
He's as hard and uncompromising as any professional sportsman.

meanings.def: definitely true and based on information that can be proved
examples: Is there any hard evidence either way?
The newspaper story is based on hard facts.

meanings.def: very cold and severe
examples: It had been a hard winter.
There was a hard frost that night.

meanings.def: strongly alcoholic
examples: hard liquor
(informal) a drop of the hard stuff (= a strong alcoholic drink)

meanings.def: containing calcium and other mineral salts that make mixing with soap difficult
examples: a hard water area
Our water is very hard.

meanings.def: used to describe a letter c or g when pronounced as in ‘cat’ or ‘go’, rather than as in ‘city’ or ‘giant’
to treat or criticize somebody in a very severe or strict way
examples: Don't be too hard on him—he's very young.

meanings.def: to be difficult for or unfair to somebody/something
examples: It's hard on people who don't have a car.

meanings.def: to be likely to hurt or damage something
examples: Looking at a computer screen all day can be very hard on the eyes.

meanings.def: in a situation where you have to choose between two things, both of which are unpleasant
to argue in an aggressive way and force somebody to agree on the best possible price or arrangement
to deliberately make a situation difficult and unpleasant for somebody
examples: They really gave me a hard time at the interview.

meanings.def: that cannot be changed in any circumstances
examples: There are no hard and fast rules about this.
This situation isn’t hard and fast.

meanings.def: showing no fear, sympathy or kind behaviour
used as a way of saying that you are sorry about something, usually ironically (= you really mean the opposite)
difficult to understand or needing a lot of effort
examples: I'm finding his latest novel very hard going.

meanings.def: used to tell somebody that you feel sorry for them
examples: ‘Failed again, I'm afraid.’ ‘Oh, hard luck.’

meanings.def: a difficult problem or situation to deal with
a person or event that is so good or successful at something that it will be difficult for anyone/anything else coming after them to be as good or successful
examples: She has been an excellent principal and will be a hard act to follow.
Their contribution will prove a tough act to follow.

meanings.def: by having an unpleasant experience or by making mistakes
examples: She won't listen to my advice so she'll just have to learn the hard way.
He learned about the dangers of drugs the hard way.

meanings.def: to have difficulty doing something
examples: You'll have a job convincing them that you're right.
He had a hard job to make himself heard.
He'll have a tough job getting the team into shape in time.
It's very dark out there, you'll have a job to see anything.

meanings.def: to use more time or energy on a task than is necessary
used after you have been arguing with somebody or have beaten them in a contest but you would still like to be friendly with them
examples: It looks like I'm the winner again. No hard feelings, Dave, eh?
Someone has to lose. No hard feelings, eh?

meanings.def: to make yourself seem more attractive or interesting by not immediately accepting an invitation to do something
to consider a problem or possibility very carefully and without hurrying
examples: We need to take a long, hard look at all the options.

meanings.def: needing too much effort
examples: I can't be bothered making a hot meal—it's too much like hard work.

idioms.def: to treat or criticize somebody in a very severe or strict way
examples: Don't be too hard on him—he's very young.
It's hard on people who don't have a car.
Looking at a computer screen all day can be very hard on the eyes.

idioms.def: needing too much effort

meanings.def: with great effort; with difficulty
examples: to work hard
You must try harder.
She tried her hardest not to show how disappointed she was.
He was still breathing hard after his run.
You shouldn't train too hard—be careful about injuries.
He is fighting hard to keep his job.
She trained hard twice a day.
Our victory was hard won (= won with great difficulty).
I have to work hard today.
She has thought very hard about her future plans.
It was raining hard outside.
I hardly ever go to concerts.
I can hardly wait for my birthday.
I’ve been working hardly today.
She has thought very hardly about her future plans.
It was raining hardly outside.
He had studied hard to become an engineer.
I trained as hard as I could.
The industry has been lobbying hard for cuts in electricity pricing.
They prayed hard for rain.

meanings.def: with great force
examples: Don't hit it so hard!
I pressed the accelerator hard and the car sped off.
(figurative) Small businesses have been hit hard/hard hit by the recession.

meanings.def: carefully and completely
examples: to think hard
We thought long and hard before deciding to move house.
They need to look hard at the facts of this case.

meanings.def: heavily; a lot or for a long time
examples: It was raining hard when we set off.

meanings.def: at a sharp angle to the left/right
examples: Turn hard right at the next junction.

meanings.def: to be or feel unfairly treated
examples: She has every right to feel hard done by—her parents have given her nothing.

meanings.def: to find it very difficult to do something
examples: He was hard put to it to explain her disappearance.

meanings.def: to have too few or too little of something
examples: We're hard up for ideas.

meanings.def: very soon after
examples: His death followed hard on hers.

meanings.def: very close behind somebody/something; very soon after something
examples: He turned and fled with Peter hot on his heels.
They reached the border with the police hot on their heels.
Further successes came hot on the heels of her first best-selling novel.
News of rising unemployment followed hard on the heels of falling export figures.

meanings.def: used to say that things change very slowly
to be very upset by something
examples: He took his wife's death very hard.

examples: She has every right to feel hard done by—her parents have given her nothing.
